link.title: Tutorial - A Diffusion Model for Image Restoration

entry.content:
Introduction

In this post, we talk about generative models for image restoration, taking Image Restoration with Mean-Reverting Stochastic Differential Equations (IR-SDE) as an example, a score-based diffusion model for various low-level vision tasks including denoising, super resolution, deraining, etc.

Background of Score-based Diffusion Models through SDEs

First, let’s briefly review the basic framework of score-based diffusion models. Let $\mathbf{x}_0 \sim p_0(\mathbf{x})$ denote a sample $\mathbf{x}_0 \in \mathbb{R}^d$ drawn from the initial ground truth data distribution $p_0(\mathbf{x})$. After adding a small amount of noise to $\mathbf{x}_0$, we have a slightly noise-perturbed sample $\mathbf{x}_1 \in \mathbb{R}^d$. By repeating this step for $N$ (e.g., $N$ could be thousands) steps, we obtain a sequence of noisy samples $\{ \mathbf{x}_i \}_{i=0}^N \in \mathbb{R}^d$ indexed by the step variable $i$.

Generalizing the discrete step variable $i$ to a continuous time variable $t$, we have a continuous forward diffusion process $\{ \mathbf{x}(t) \}_{t=0}^T \in \mathbb{R}^d$. With sufficiently large $T$, $\mathbf{x}(T)$ is completely noisy without any information about the initial data $\mathbf{x}(0)$.

Note that the initial data distribution $p_0(\mathbf{x})$ is often intractable. However, given a well-defined forward diffusion process, the final noisy sample distribution $\mathbf{x}(T) \sim p_T(\mathbf{x})$ can be in a tractable form (e.g., a standard Gaussian distribution $\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0}, \mathbf{I})$).

To generate samples from such an intractable data distribution $p_0(\mathbf{x})$, a potential way is to reverse the forward diffusion process such that we sample $\mathbf{x}(T)$ from a tractable prior distribution $p_T(\mathbf{x})$, then generate intermediate noisy data $\mathbf{x}(t) \sim p_t(\mathbf{x})$, and finally the clean data $\mathbf{x}(0) \sim p_0(\mathbf{x})$ through a tractable reverse diffusion process running backwards in time, $T o 0$.

In order to achieve this goal, we often start with a tractable prior distribution $p_T(\mathbf{x})$ (e.g., a standard Gaussian distribution $\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0}, \mathbf{I})$). The forward diffusion process is modeled by a stochastic differential equation (SDE) to perturbe data such that the final output will end up being completely noisy and follow the prior distribution $p_T(\mathbf{x})$.

Formally, the SDE for the forward diffusion process can be constructed in the form of:

egin{equation} \label{eq:forward} \mathrm{d} \mathbf{x} = \mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}, t) \mathrm{d} t + g(t)\mathrm{d} \mathbf{w} \end{equation}

where $\mathbf{w}$ is the standard Wiener process (a.k.a., Brownian motion) (time flow: $0 o T$), $\mathrm{d}t$ is an infinitesimal positive time interval, and $f(\mathbf{x}, t)$ and $g(t)$ are called the drift and diffusion coefficients of $\mathbf{x}$, respectively. Solving the above forward SDE, the intermediate noise-perturbed sample $\mathbf{x}(t)$ can be obtained given the initial data sample $\mathbf{x}(0)$.

Note that, the actual SDE can be in different forms such that the prior distribution $p_T(\mathbf{x})$ will have different forms, rather than just limited to standard Gaussiance distribution $\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0}, \mathbf{I})$. However, we do not have to solve the forward SDE as our goal is to reverse the forward diffusion process or the SDE for generating data $\mathbf{x}(0)$ starting from the noise/prior $\mathbf{x}(T) \sim p_T(\mathbf{x})$:

An important property of the diffusion process modeled by the above SDE (Eq. \eqref{eq:forward}): its reverse process running backwards in time is also a diffusion process modeled by a reverse-time SDE corresponding to the forward SDE.

egin{equation} \label{eq:reverse} \mathrm{d}\mathbf{x} = [ \mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}, t) - g(t)^2 \underbrace{ abla_{\mathbf{x}}\log{p_t(\mathbf{x})} }_{ ext{score: } s_{ heta}(\mathbf{x}, t)} ] \mathrm{d}t + g(t)\mathrm{d}\mathbf{ ar{w}} \end{equation}

where $\mathbf{ ar{w}}$ is a standard reverse-time Wiener process (time flow: $T o 0$), $\mathrm{d}t$ is an infinitesimal negative time interval, and $s_{ heta}(\mathbf{x}, t)= abla_{\mathbf{x}}\log{p_t(\mathbf{x})}$ is called the score of the marginal distribution $p_t(\mathbf{x})$ for $\mathbf{x}(t)$ at time $t$. Note that the score function $s_{ heta}(\mathbf{x}, t)$ is often intractable and needs to be approximated by a neural network learned from data.

Image Restoration with Mean-reverting SDE

In diffusion models, given a sample from the prior distribution, $\mathbf{x}(T) \sim p_T(\mathbf{x})$, we can generate data from the data distribution, $\mathbf{x}(0) \sim p_0(\mathbf{x})$, through the reverse-time SDE. In the problem of image restoration, given the low-quality (LQ) data (e.g., low-resolution images), the goal is to generate high-quality (HQ) data (e.g., high-resolution images). Corresponding to the framework of the SDE-based diffusion processes, we have:

  • LQ: known prior distribution, $\mathbf{x}(T) \sim p_T(\mathbf{x})$,
  • HQ: unknown data distribution, $\mathbf{x}(0) \sim p_0(\mathbf{x})$

Mean-reverting SDE

To adapt to the SDE-based diffusion model framework, we need to design a SDE that perturbes the HQ sample $\mathbf{x}(0)$ such that the final noisy counterpart $\mathbf{x}(T)$ follow the same distribution of LQ data.

A special form of the forward SDE was hand designed to satisfy this prerequisite. Let

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} \mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}, t) &= heta_t( oldsymbol{\mu} - \mathbf{x}) \ g(t) &= \sigma_t \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

We have a special SDE:

\[ egin{equation} \label{eq:irsde} \mathrm{d}\mathbf{x} = heta_t( oldsymbol{\mu} - \mathbf{x}) \mathrm{d}t + \sigma_t \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w} \end{equation}\]

where \(\mu\) is the LQ sample, $ heta_t$ and $\sigma_t$ are time-dependent hyperparameters. To sovle the SDE (Eq. \eqref{eq:irsde}), let’s first define a function

\[ egin{equation} \phi(\mathbf{x}, t) = \mathbf{x} \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_t} \end{equation}\]

where $\mathbf{x}(t) \sim p_t(\mathbf{x})$ is the data sample at time $t$ and $ ar{ heta}_t=\int_0^t heta_z \mathrm{d}z$. We can get the differential equation of $\phi(\mathbf{x}, t)$:

\[ egin{equation} \mathrm{d} \phi(\mathbf{x}, t) = \mathbf{x} \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_t} rac{\partial ar{ heta}_t}{\partial t} \mathrm{d}t + \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_t} \mathrm{d} \mathbf{x} \end{equation}\]

Note that $ ar{ heta}_t=\int_0^t heta_z \mathrm{d}z$, $ rac{\partial ar{ heta}_t}{\partial t} = heta_t$. Also substituting $\mathrm{d} \mathbf{x}$ with Eq. \eqref{eq:irsde}, we have

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} \mathrm{d} \phi(\mathbf{x}, t) &= \mathbf{x} \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_t} rac{\partial ar{ heta}_t}{\partial t} \mathrm{d}t + \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_t} \mathrm{d} \mathbf{x} \ &= \mathbf{x} \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_t} heta_t \mathrm{d}t + \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_t} [ heta_t( oldsymbol{\mu} - \mathbf{x}) \mathrm{d}t + \sigma_t \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_t] \ &= [\cancel{\mathbf{x} heta_t \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_t}} + oldsymbol{\mu} heta_t \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_t} - \cancel{\mathbf{x} heta_t \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_t}}] \mathrm{d}t + \sigma_t \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_t} \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_t \ &= oldsymbol{\mu} heta_t \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_t} \mathrm{d}t + \sigma_t \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_t} \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_t \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

where we change $\mathbf{w}$ to $\mathbf{w}_t$ to explicitly express its change over time $t$. As such, we have the relationship between $\phi(\mathbf{x}, t)$ and $\phi(\mathbf{x}, s)$ at any two different times $s < t$:

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} \phi(\mathbf{x}, t) - \phi(\mathbf{x}, s) &= \int_s^t \mathrm{d} \phi(\mathbf{x}, z) \ &= \int_s^t ( oldsymbol{\mu} heta_z \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_z} \mathrm{d}z + \sigma_z \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_z} \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_z) \ &= \int_s^t oldsymbol{\mu} heta_z \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_z} \mathrm{d}z + \int_s^t \sigma_z \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_z} \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_z \ \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

Substitute $\phi(\mathbf{x}, t)$ with $\mathbf{x} \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_t}$ and divide both sides of the above equation by $\mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_t}$, we have

\[ egin{equation} \label{eq:xts} egin{aligned} \mathbf{x}(t) \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_t} - \mathbf{x}(s) \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_s} &= \int_s^t oldsymbol{\mu} heta_z \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_z} \mathrm{d}z + \int_s^t \sigma_z \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_z} \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_z \ \Longrightarrow \mathbf{x}(t) - \mathbf{x}(s) \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_s - ar{ heta}_t} &= \int_s^t oldsymbol{\mu} heta_z \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_z - ar{ heta}_t} \mathrm{d}z + \int_s^t \sigma_z \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_z - ar{ heta}_t} \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_z \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

Recall that $ ar{ heta}_t=\int_0^t heta_z \mathrm{d}z$. Given $0 < s < t$, we have

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} \mathrm{e}^{ ar{ heta}_s - ar{ heta}_t} &= \mathrm{e}^{\int_0^s heta_z \mathrm{d}z - \int_0^t heta_z \mathrm{d}z} \ &= \mathrm{e}^{-\int_s^t heta_z \mathrm{d}z}\ & = \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{s:t}} \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

Rewriting the above Eq. \eqref{eq:xts}, we obtain

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} \mathbf{x}(t) - \mathbf{x}(s) \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{s:t}} &= \int_s^t oldsymbol{\mu} heta_z \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{z:t}} \mathrm{d}z + \int_s^t \sigma_z \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{z:t}} \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_z \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

Note that $\mathrm{d}(- ar{ heta}_{z:t}) = \mathrm{d} (-\int_z^t heta_z \mathrm{d}z) = heta_z$

\[ egin{equation} \int_s^t oldsymbol{\mu} heta_z \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{z:t}} \mathrm{d}z = oldsymbol{\mu} \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{z:t}} igg|_s^t = oldsymbol{\mu} (\mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{t:t}} - \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{s:t}}) = oldsymbol{\mu} (1-\mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{s:t}}) \end{equation}\] \[ egin{equation} \label{eq:solution_irsde} egin{aligned} \mathbf{x}(t) &= \mathbf{x}(s) \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{s:t}} + oldsymbol{\mu} (1-\mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{s:t}}) + \int_s^t \sigma_z \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{z:t}} \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_z \ \mathbf{x}(t) &= oldsymbol{\mu} + (\mathbf{x}(s) - oldsymbol{\mu}) \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{s:t}} + \int_s^t \sigma_z \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{z:t}} \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_z \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

which is the solution to the SDE in Eq. \eqref{eq:irsde}. For any starting sample $\mathbf{x}_s$ at time $s$, we can generate the noise-perturbed sample $\mathbf{x}_t$ at time $t$. Looking into the expectation of the Eq. \eqref{eq:solution_irsde}, we have

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[\mathbf{x}(t)] &= \mathbb{E}\left[ oldsymbol{\mu} + (\mathbf{x}(s) - oldsymbol{\mu}) \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{s:t}} + \int_s^t \sigma_z \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{z:t}} \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_z ight] \ &= \mathbb{E}\left[ oldsymbol{\mu} + (\mathbf{x}(s) - oldsymbol{\mu}) \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{s:t}} ight] + \mathbb{E}\left[\int_s^t \sigma_z \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{z:t}} \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_z ight] \ \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

Since the first part $\mu + (\mathbf{x}(s) - \mu) \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{s:t}}$ is deterministic, its expectation is itself

\[ egin{equation} \mathbb{E}\left[ oldsymbol{\mu} + (\mathbf{x}(s) - oldsymbol{\mu}) \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{s:t}} ight] = oldsymbol{\mu} + (\mathbf{x}(s) - oldsymbol{\mu}) \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{s:t}} \end{equation}\]

Regarding the second part $\mathbb{E}\left[\int_s^t \sigma_z \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{z:t}} \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_z ight]$, let’s first review some Itô basics.

Theorem. Let $\mathbf{w}_t$ be a Wiener process, and $\Delta(t)$ be a nonrandom function of time. Suppose that a stochastic process $\mathbf{h}(t)$ satisfies

\[ egin{equation} \mathrm{d} \mathbf{h} = \Delta(z)\mathrm{d}\mathbf{w}_z \ \mathbf{h}(t) = \int \Delta(z) \mathrm{d}\mathbf{w}_z \end{equation}\]

where $\mathbf{h}(0)=0$. Then, for each $t>=0$, the random variable $\mathbf{h}(t)$ is normally distributed.

Let $\Delta(z) = \sigma_z \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{z:t}}$ which is nonrandom, $\mathbf{h}(t) = \int_s^t \Delta(z) \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_z$, we have

\[ egin{equation} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_s^t \sigma_z \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{z:t}} \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_z ight] = \mathbb{E}\left[\int_s^t \Delta(z) \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_z ight] = \mathbb{E}[\mathbf{h}(t)] = \mathbf{0} \end{equation}\]

We can further derive the covariance of $I(t)$.

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} \mathrm{Cov}\left(\mathbf{h}(t) ight) &= \mathbb{E} \left[ \left(\mathbf{h}(t)-\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{h}(t)] ight) \left(\mathbf{h}(t)-\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{h}(t)] ight)^ op ight] \ &= \mathbb{E} \left[ \mathbf{h}(t) \mathbf{h}(t)^ op ight]\ &= \mathbb{E}\left[ \left(\int_s^t \Delta(z) \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_z ight) \left(\int_s^t \Delta(z) \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_z ight)^ op ight]\ \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

Since $\mathbf{h}(t) = \int_s^t \Delta(z) \, \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_z$, we can apply the Itô isometry to compute the covariance matrix. For any two components $\mathbf{h}^{(i)}(t)$ and $\mathbf{h}^{(j)}(t)$ of $\mathbf{h}(t)$, we have:

\[ egin{equation} \mathbb{E}\left[ \mathbf{h}^{(i)}(t) \mathbf{h}^{(j)}(t) ight] = \mathbb{E}\left[ \int_s^t \Delta(z) \, \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_z^{(i)} \int_s^t \Delta(z) \, \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_z^{(j)} ight]. \end{equation}\]

Since the Wiener processes $\mathbf{w}_z^{(i)}$ and $\mathbf{w}_z^{(j)}$ are independent for $i eq j$, the cross terms $\mathbb{E}\left[ \mathbf{h}^{(i)}(t) \mathbf{h}^{(j)}(t) ight] = 0$ when $i eq j$. For the diagonal terms where $i = j$, the Itô isometry gives:

\[ egin{equation} \mathbb{E}\left[ \left( \mathbf{h}^{(i)}(t) ight)^2 ight] = \mathbb{E}\left[ \left( \int_s^t \Delta(z) \, \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_z^{(i)} ight)^2 ight] = \int_s^t \Delta(z)^2 \, \mathrm{d}z. \end{equation}\]

Thus, the covariance matrix $ ext{Cov}(\mathbf{h}(t))$ is a diagonal matrix, where each diagonal entry is $\int_s^t \Delta(z)^2 \, \mathrm{d}z$.

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} \mathrm{Cov}\left(\mathbf{h}(t) ight) &= \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\int_s^t \Delta(z)^2 \mathrm{d}z ight) ight] \cdot \mathbf{I} \quad (\mathbf{I} ext{ is identity matrix})\ &= \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\int_s^t \left(\sigma_z \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{z:t}} ight)^2 \mathrm{d}z ight) ight] \cdot \mathbf{I}\ &= \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\int_s^t \sigma_z^2 \mathrm{e}^{-2 ar{ heta}_{z:t}} \mathrm{d}z ight) ight] \cdot \mathbf{I}\ &= \mathbb{E}\left[ rac{\sigma_z^2}{2 heta_z} \mathrm{e}^{-2 ar{ heta}_{z:t}} igg|_s^t ight] \cdot \mathbf{I}\ &= \mathbb{E}\left[ rac{\sigma_t^2}{2 heta_t} \mathrm{e}^{-2 ar{ heta}_{t:t}} - rac{\sigma_s^2}{2 heta_s} \mathrm{e}^{-2 ar{ heta}_{s:t}} ight] \cdot \mathbf{I}\ &= \mathbb{E}\left[ rac{\sigma_t^2}{2 heta_t} \mathrm{e}^0 - rac{\sigma_s^2}{2 heta_s} \mathrm{e}^{-2 ar{ heta}_{s:t}} ight] \cdot \mathbf{I}\ &= \mathbb{E}\left[ \lambda^2 - \lambda^2 \mathrm{e}^{-2 ar{ heta}_{s:t}} ight] \cdot \mathbf{I} \quad (\sigma_t^2 / heta_t = 2\lambda^2, 0 < t < T) \ &= \lambda^2 \left( 1- \mathrm{e}^{-2 ar{ heta}_{s:t}} ight) \cdot \mathbf{I} \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

Therefore, we have

\[ egin{equation} \mathbf{h}(t) \sim \mathcal{N} \left( \mathbf{0}, \lambda^2 \left( 1- \mathrm{e}^{-2 ar{ heta}_{s:t}} ight) \cdot \mathbf{I} ight) \end{equation}\]

Note that $\mathbf{x}(t) \sim p_t(\mathbf{x})$ also follows Gaussian distribution:

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} \mathbf{x}(t) &= oldsymbol{\mu} + \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{s:t}} \cdot \left[ \mathbf{x}(s) - oldsymbol{\mu} ight] + \int_s^t \sigma_z \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{z:t}} \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_z \ &= oldsymbol{\mu} + \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{s:t}} \cdot \left[\mathbf{x}(s) - oldsymbol{\mu} ight] + \mathbf{h}(t) \ \end{aligned} \end{equation}\] \[ egin{equation} \label{eq:mu_std} egin{aligned} p(\mathbf{x}(t) | \mathbf{x}(s)) &= \mathcal{N} \left( \mathbf{x}(t) | oldsymbol{\mu}_{s:t}(\mathbf{x}(s)), \mathbf{\Sigma}_{s:t} ight) \ oldsymbol{\mu}_{s:t}(\mathbf{x}(s)) &= oldsymbol{\mu} + \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{s:t}} \cdot \left[ \mathbf{x}(s) - oldsymbol{\mu} ight] \ \mathbf{\Sigma}_{s:t} &= ext{Cov}(\mathbf{h}(t)) = \lambda^2 \left( 1- \mathrm{e}^{-2 ar{ heta}_{s:t}} ight)\cdot \mathbf{I} \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

We observe that, with $t o \infty$, the mean of $\mathbf{x}_t$, $\mu_{s:t}(\mathbf{x}_s)$ converges to the LQ sample $\mu$ and the covariance $\Sigma_{s:t}$ converges to $\lambda^2$, which is called the stationary variance in the IR-SDE paper . Therefore, if starting with the initial HQ sample $\mathbf{x}_s = \mathbf{x}_0$, the hand-designed SDE in Eq. \eqref{eq:irsde} established a framework of an SDE-based diffusion model for image restoration, diffusing $\mathbf{x}_0$ to its noisy counterpart, the LQ sample $\mathbf{x}_T$.

Reversing the SDE

By Eq. \eqref{eq:reverse}, the reverse-time SDE corresponding to the SDE (Eq. \eqref{eq:irsde}) is:

\[ egin{equation} \label{eq:reverse_irsde_custom} egin{aligned} \mathrm{d}\mathbf{x} &= [\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}, t) - g(t)^2 abla_{\mathbf{x}}\log{p_t(\mathbf{x})}]\mathrm{d}t + g(t)\mathrm{d}\mathbf{ ar{w}} \ &= \left[ heta_t ( oldsymbol{\mu} - \mathbf{x}) - \sigma_t^2 abla_{\mathbf{x}} \log p_t(\mathbf{x}) ight] \mathrm{d}t + \sigma_t \mathrm{d} ar{\mathbf{w}} \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

With this reverse-time SDE flowing backwards in time $T o 0$, we can starting from the LQ sample $\mathbf{x}(T) \sim p_T(\mathbf{x})$ and generate the HQ sample $\mathbf{x}(0) \sim p_0(\mathbf{x})$. However, we still have an unknown part, the score $ abla_{\mathbf{x}} \log p_t(\mathbf{x})$, in the reverse-time SDE.

As the score function $ abla_{\mathbf{x}} \log p_t(\mathbf{x})$ is intractable for real-world data, it is often approximated by a neural network trained with ground-truth HQ-LQ sample pairs, $\left(\mathbf{x}(0), \mathbf{x}(T) ight)$. To train a neural network mode $s_{ heta}(\mathbf{x}(t), t)$ given time $t$ and the intermediate noisy sample $\mathbf{x}(t)$, we first compute the conditional ground-truth score $ abla_{\mathbf{x}} \log p_t(\mathbf{x} | \mathbf{x}(0))$ given the HQ sample $\mathbf{x}(0)$. Note that

\[ egin{equation} \label{eq:prob_s_t} p(\mathbf{x}(t) | \mathbf{x}(s)) = \mathcal{N} \left( \mathbf{x}(t) | oldsymbol{\mu}_{s:t}(\mathbf{x}(s)), \mathbf{\Sigma}_{s:t} ight) \end{equation}\]

we have

\[ egin{equation} p_t(\mathbf{x} | \mathbf{x}(0)) = \mathcal{N} \left( \mathbf{x}(t) | oldsymbol{\mu}_{0:t}(\mathbf{x}(0)), \mathbf{\Sigma}_{0:t} ight) \end{equation}\]

To simplify notation, we replace all subscripts $\{ * \}_{0:t}$ with $\{ * \}_{t}$. Thus, we have

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} p_t(\mathbf{x} | \mathbf{x}(0)) &= \mathcal{N} \left( \mathbf{x}(t) | oldsymbol{\mu}_{t}, \mathbf{\Sigma}_{t} ight) \ &= rac{1}{(2 \pi)^{d/2} |\mathbf{\Sigma}_{t}|^{1/2}} \exp\left( - rac{1}{2} \left(\mathbf{x}(t) - oldsymbol{\mu}_{t} ight)^ op \mathbf{\Sigma}_{t}^{-1} \left(\mathbf{x}(t) - oldsymbol{\mu}_{t} ight) ight) \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

Hence, the score has the following closed-form solution:

\[ egin{equation} abla_{\mathbf{x}} \log p_t(\mathbf{x} | \mathbf{x}(0)) = -\mathbf{\Sigma}_{t}^{-1} \left( \mathbf{x}(t) - oldsymbol{\mu}_{t} ight) \end{equation}\]

Training Objectives

Noise Prediction

With ground-truth clean sample $\mathbf{x}(0)$ in training, we first perturbe $\mathbf{x}(0)$ through the diffusion process via the forward SDE and obtain the noise-perturbed sample $\mathbf{x}(t)$.

Next, we compute the mean $\mu_{t}$ and covariance $\Sigma_{t}$ by Eq. \eqref{eq:mu_std} such that we can obtain the ground-truth score $ abla_{\mathbf{x}}\log{p_t(\mathbf{x}|\mathbf{x}(0))}$ for training the score network $\mathbf{s}_{ heta}(\mathbf{x}(t),t)$.

During inference, the reverse-time SDE starts from the final time $T$ such that the score network approximates the score at time $T$ given the most noisy input LQ sample, $\mathbf{x}(T)$. Ideally, after iteratively running backwards in time, $T o 0$, the reverse process will generate the clean HQ sample, $\mathbf{x}(0)$, via the reverse-time SDE (Eq. \eqref{eq:reverse_irsde_custom}). However, the actual performance might not be as expected, as detailed in many studies.

Considering the conditional distribution, $p_t(\mathbf{x} | \mathbf{x}(0)) \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu_t, \Sigma_t)$, we have $\mathbf{x}(t) = \mu_{t} + |\Sigma_t|^{1/2} \epsilon_t$, where $\epsilon_t \sim \mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0}, \mathbf{I})$. The score is reparameterized as

\[ egin{equation} abla_{\mathbf{x}} \log p_t(\mathbf{x} | \mathbf{x}(0)) = -\mathbf{\Sigma}_{t}^{-1/2} oldsymbol{\epsilon}_t \end{equation}\]

Therefore, we can, instead, train a noise network $ ilde{\epsilon}_{\phi}(\mathbf{x}(t), \mu, t)$ which takes the intermediate noisy sample $\mathbf{x}(t)$, the LQ sample or condition $\mu$, and the time $t$ as input and outputs the noise to approximate the ground-truth noise $\epsilon_t$.

The noise network can be trained following a similar framework proposed in the work Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models (DDPM) by minimizing the following loss (after discretization from continuous time variable $t \in [0, T]$ to discretized step variable $\{ i\}_{i=0}^N$):

\[ egin{equation} L_{\gamma}(\phi) = \sum_{i=1}^{N}\gamma_i \mathbb{E} \left[ \Vert ilde{ oldsymbol{\epsilon}}_{\phi}(\mathbf{x}_i, oldsymbol{\mu}, i) - oldsymbol{\epsilon}_i \Vert ight] \end{equation}\]

where, for the $i^{ ext{th}}$ step in the diffusion process, $\gamma_i$ denotes the weight, $\mathbf{x}_i$ represents the intermediate noisy sample, and ${\epsilon}_i$ is the ground-truth randomly sampled Gaussian noise.

After the noise network $ ilde{\epsilon}_{\phi}(\mathbf{x}_i, {\mu}, i)$ is trained, we can start from the LQ sample $\mathbf{x}_N$ and iteratively solve the reverse-time SDE with numerical approaches (e.g., Euler-Maruyama or stochastic Runge-Kutta methods) for generating the HQ sample $\mathbf{x}_0$. More details can be found in the study, Score-based Diffusion Models through SDE .

Maximum Likelihood

Unfortunately, the above objective $L_{\gamma}(\phi)$ did not produce good HQ samples in experiments while there is not good reason in the original paper explaining this issue. Instead, a new maximum likelihood objective was proposed for training the noise network.

In this part, let’s the diffusion process at discrete times $\{i\}_{i=0}^N$ and the Markov property. The joint probability of $(\mathbf{x}_1, \mathbf{x}_2, \dots, \mathbf{x}_N )$ conditioned on $\mathbf{x}_0$ is

\[ egin{equation} p(\mathbf{x}_{1:N}|\mathbf{x}_0) = p(\mathbf{x}_N|\mathbf{x}_0) \prod_{i=2}^N p(\mathbf{x}_{i-1}|\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{x}_0) \end{equation}\]

where we consider the intermediate noisy sample $\mathbf{x}_{i-1}$ is conditioned on both the initial HQ sample $\mathbf{x}_0$ and the next noise-perturbed sample $\mathbf{x}_{i}$.

Using Bayes’ rule, the reverse transition, $p(\mathbf{x}_{i-1} | \mathbf{x}_i, \mathbf{x}_0)$ can be expressed as

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} p(\mathbf{x}_{i-1}|\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{x}_0) &= rac{p(\mathbf{x}_{i}|\mathbf{x}_{i-1}, \mathbf{x}_0) p(\mathbf{x}_{i-1}|\mathbf{x}_0)}{p(\mathbf{x}_i|\mathbf{x}_0)} \ &= rac{p(\mathbf{x}_{i}|\mathbf{x}_{i-1}) p(\mathbf{x}_{i-1}|\mathbf{x}_0)}{p(\mathbf{x}_i|\mathbf{x}_0)} \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

where each of the above probabilities are Gaussian (Eq. \eqref{eq:prob_s_t}). The goal is to find the optimal $\mathbf{x}_{i-1}^*$ to maximize the likelihood $p(\mathbf{x}_{i-1} | \mathbf{x}_i, \mathbf{x}_0)$ or minimize the negative log likelihood (NLL) $- \log p(\mathbf{x}_{i-1} | \mathbf{x}_i, \mathbf{x}_0)$.

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} \mathbf{x}_{i-1}^* &= \arg \max_{\mathbf{x}_{i-1}} \left[ p(\mathbf{x}_{i-1}|\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{x}_0) ight] \ &= \arg \max_{\mathbf{x}_{i-1}} \left[ p(\mathbf{x}_{i}|\mathbf{x}_{i-1}) p(\mathbf{x}_{i-1}|\mathbf{x}_0) ight] \ &= \arg \min_{\mathbf{x}_{i-1}} \left[ -\log p(\mathbf{x}_{i}|\mathbf{x}_{i-1}) - \log p(\mathbf{x}_{i-1}|\mathbf{x}_0) ight] \ \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

The discretized version of the transition kernel, $p(\mathbf{x}_t | \mathbf{x}_s)$, between times $s$ and $t$, becomes:

\[ egin{equation} \label{eq:prob_s_t_discrete} egin{aligned} p(\mathbf{x}_t | \mathbf{x}_s) &= \mathcal{N} \left( \mathbf{x}_t | oldsymbol{\mu}_{s:t}(\mathbf{x}_s), \mathbf{\Sigma}_{s:t} ight) \ oldsymbol{\mu}_{s:t}(\mathbf{x}_s) &= oldsymbol{\mu} + \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{s:t}} \cdot \left[ \mathbf{x}_s - oldsymbol{\mu} ight] \ \mathbf{\Sigma}_{s:t} &= ext{Cov}(\mathbf{h}_t) = \lambda^2 \left( 1- \mathrm{e}^{-2 ar{ heta}_{s:t}} ight)\cdot \mathbf{I} \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

As the transitions $p(\mathbf{x}_{i} | \mathbf{x}_{i-1})$ and $p(\mathbf{x}_{i-1} | \mathbf{x}_0)$ have been derived in Eq. \eqref{eq:prob_s_t_discrete}, we can solve the above optimization problem by taking the derivative.

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} & - abla_{\mathbf{x}_{i-1}} \log p(\mathbf{x}_{i}|\mathbf{x}_{i-1}) - abla_{\mathbf{x}_{i-1}} \log p(\mathbf{x}_{i-1}|\mathbf{x}_0) \ = & - \mathbf{\Sigma}_{(i-1):i}^{-1} (\mathbf{x}_{i} - oldsymbol{\mu}_{(i-1):i})\mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{(i-1):i}} - \mathbf{\Sigma}_{0:(i-1)}^{-1} (\mathbf{x}_{i-1} - oldsymbol{\mu}_{0:(i-1)}) \ = & - rac{\mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{(i-1):i}}}{\lambda^2 \left( 1- \mathrm{e}^{-2 ar{ heta}_{(i-1):i}} ight)} (\mathbf{x}_{i} - oldsymbol{\mu} - \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{(i-1):i}} \cdot ( \mathbf{x}_{i-1} - oldsymbol{\mu} )) \ & + rac{1}{\lambda^2 \left( 1- \mathrm{e}^{-2 ar{ heta}_{0:(i-1)}} ight)} (\mathbf{x}_{i-1} - oldsymbol{\mu} - \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{0:(i-1)}} \cdot \left( \mathbf{x}_0 - oldsymbol{\mu} ight)) \ = & 0 \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

Setting the above derivative to 0 and solving the equation, we have:

\[ egin{equation} \mathbf{x}_{i-1}^* = rac{1- \mathrm{e}^{-2 ar{ heta}_{0:(i-1)}}}{1- \mathrm{e}^{-2 ar{ heta}_{0:i}}} \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{(i-1):i}} (\mathbf{x}_{i}- oldsymbol{\mu}) + rac{1- \mathrm{e}^{-2 ar{ heta}_{(i-1):i}}}{1- \mathrm{e}^{-2 ar{ heta}_{0:i}}} \mathrm{e}^{- ar{ heta}_{0:(i-1)}} (\mathbf{x}_{0}- oldsymbol{\mu}) + oldsymbol{\mu} \end{equation}\]

Given that the second-order derivative with respect to $\mathbf{x}_{i-1}$ is positive:

\[ egin{equation} rac{\mathrm{e}^{-2 ar{ heta}_{(i-1):i}}}{\lambda^2 \left( 1- \mathrm{e}^{-2 ar{ heta}_{(i-1):i}} ight)} + rac{1}{\lambda^2 \left( 1- \mathrm{e}^{-2 ar{ heta}_{0:(i-1)}} ight)} > 0 \end{equation}\]

The solution $\mathbf{x}_{i-1}^*$ is a global optimal.

—–The End—–

entry.title: a post with pseudo code
entry.content:
This is an example post with some pseudo code rendered by pseudocode. The example presented here is the same as the one in the pseudocode.js documentation, with only one simple but important change: everytime you would use $, you should use $$ instead. Also, note that the pseudocode key in the front matter is set to true to enable the rendering of pseudo code. As an example, using this code:

```pseudocode
% This quicksort algorithm is extracted from Chapter 7, Introduction to Algorithms (3rd edition)
\begin{algorithm}
\caption{Quicksort}
\begin{algorithmic}
\PROCEDURE{Quicksort}{$$A, p, r$$}
    \IF{$$p < r$$}
        \STATE $$q = $$ \CALL{Partition}{$$A, p, r$$}
        \STATE \CALL{Quicksort}{$$A, p, q - 1$$}
        \STATE \CALL{Quicksort}{$$A, q + 1, r$$}
    \ENDIF
\ENDPROCEDURE
\PROCEDURE{Partition}{$$A, p, r$$}
    \STATE $$x = A[r]$$
    \STATE $$i = p - 1$$
    \FOR{$$j = p$$ \TO $$r - 1$$}
        \IF{$$A[j] < x$$}
            \STATE $$i = i + 1$$
            \STATE exchange
            $$A[i]$$ with $$A[j]$$
        \ENDIF
        \STATE exchange $$A[i]$$ with $$A[r]$$
    \ENDFOR
\ENDPROCEDURE
\end{algorithmic}
\end{algorithm}
```

entry.title: a post with vega lite
entry.content:
This is an example post with some vega lite code.

```vega_lite
{
  "$schema": "https://vega.github.io/schema/vega-lite/v5.json",
  "description": "A dot plot showing each movie in the database, and the difference from the average movie rating. The display is sorted by year to visualize everything in sequential order. The graph is for all Movies before 2019.",
  "data": {
    "url": "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/vega/vega/main/docs/data/movies.json"
  },
  "transform": [
    {"filter": "datum['IMDB Rating'] != null"},
    {"filter": {"timeUnit": "year", "field": "Release Date", "range": [null, 2019]}},
    {
      "joinaggregate": [{
        "op": "mean",
        "field": "IMDB Rating",
        "as": "AverageRating"
      }]
    },
    {
      "calculate": "datum['IMDB Rating'] - datum.AverageRating",
      "as": "RatingDelta"
    }
  ],
  "mark": "point",
  "encoding": {
    "x": {
      "field": "Release Date",
      "type": "temporal"
    },
    "y": {
      "field": "RatingDelta",
      "type": "quantitative",
      "title": "Rating Delta"
    },
    "color": {
      "field": "RatingDelta",
      "type": "quantitative",
      "scale": {"domainMid": 0},
      "title": "Rating Delta"
    }
  }
}
```

Which generates:
